This looks pretty good.  Most of my comments are minor.  Please let me know if you have any questions.

---

Reviewed 9 of 9 files at r1, 1 of 1 files at r2.
Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 19 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed.

---

*[Makefile, line 2990 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNLMTpBxZ99b-Yzdl1:-KhNLMTpBxZ99b-Yzdl2:br84e80) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/Makefile#L2990)):*

>     src/core/tsi/ssl_transport_security.c \
>     src/core/tsi/transport_security.c \
>     src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c \
> ```

Our Makefile is generated from a template, so you can't modify it directly. Instead, please modify the BUILD file and the build.yaml file and then run ./tools/buildgen/generate_projects.sh.

*[memory_usage.csv, line 1 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNLTynpCBZkRDhYyv_:-KhNLTynpCBZkRDhYyva:byw7z0u) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/memory_usage.csv#L1)):*

> 5678.136000,512736,4195801,5849.316778,204605,,
> ```

What is this file?  I assume this was added by mistake?

*[src/core/tsi/transport_security.c, line 185 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNMvym54x4p6SdNK0w:-KhNMvym54x4p6SdNK0x:b-4j7f9a) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security.c#L185)):*
> ```C
>                                                 protector);
>   if (result == TSI_OK) {
>     self->frame_protector_created = 1;
> ```

s/1/true/

---

*[src/core/tsi/transport_security.c, line 196 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNMnI5UkhsgbTFvt60:-KhNMnI5UkhsgbTFvt61:b20ej1z) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security.c#L196)):*
> ```C
>     tsi_handshaker_on_next_done_cb cb, void *user_data) {
>   if (self == NULL) return TSI_INVALID_ARGUMENT;
>   if (self->handshaker_result_created) return TSI_FAILED_PRECONDITION;
> ```

When does `handshaker_result_created` get set?

---

*[src/core/tsi/transport_security.h, line 94 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNMFaGJNjAbQVHtBd_:-KhNMFaHoBspdOz7_CEl:baf3g2v) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security.h#L94)):*
>   int frame_protector_created;
>   int handshaker_result_created;

These can probably be `bool`.

---

*[src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c, line 48 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNPIDCdiDYXAYv5gdr:-KhNPIDCdiDYXAYv5gds:b-dwnjud) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c#L48)):*
> ```C
> typedef struct {
>   tsi_handshaker_result base;
>   tsi_handshaker *handshaker;
> ```

Doesn't this implementation require that the underlying handshaker continue to exist until after the tsi_handshaker_result is destroyed?  How do we guarantee that?  Perhaps we need to refcount the handshaker object?  Or can we just assume that the few applications that will use this adapter will do the right thing until the adapter goes away?

---

*[src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c, line 77 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNOjJmFOM5nhABbh6I:-KhNOjJmFOM5nhABbh6J:bdhxubv) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c#L77)):*
> ```C
> static void tsi_adapter_result_destroy(tsi_handshaker_result *self) {
>   tsi_adapter_handshaker_result *impl = (tsi_adapter_handshaker_result *)self;
>   if (impl->unused_bytes != NULL) {
> ```

No need to check this.  If you call `gpr_free(NULL)`, it will be a no-op.

---

*[src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c, line 88 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNOvlQzA3LPzqLZfdt:-KhNOvlQzA3LPzqLZfdu:bkv392i) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c#L88)):*

> };

> ```

*[src/core/tsi/transport_security_interface.h, line 308 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNLhAgroXTUsdB4swp:-KhNLhAgroXTUsdB4swq:b-8771nj) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security_interface.h#L308)):*
>    A typical usage of the new TSI would be as follows, supporting both
>    synchronous and asynchrnous TSI handshaker implementations:

The term "new" will quickly grow out of date here. I suggest just saying "A typical usage supporting both synchronous and asynchronous TSI handshaker implementations would be:".

---

*[src/core/tsi/transport_security_interface.h, line 330 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNLn1jnuBzGkBO_fkY:-KhNLn1jnuBzGkBO_fkZ:b-hjcapa) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security_interface.h#L330)):*
> ```objc
>    // tsi_handshaker_next finishes. It is passed to tsi_handshaker_next as
>    // the callback function.
>    void on_handshake_next_done_wrapper(
> ```

If this example code is not intended to be gRPC-specific, then there's probably no need for a wrapper function here. Instead, I think you can just use `on_handshake_next_done()` directly.

---

*[src/core/tsi/transport_security_interface.h, line 389 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNLxF8eEETk43CvhP9:-KhNLxF9gsNV_RZeoohe:bpe4w1e) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security_interface.h#L389)):*
> ```objc
>        tsi_peer peer;
>        status = tsi_handshaker_result_extract_peer(result, &peer);
>        if (status != TSI_OK) return status;
> ```

This function returns void.

---

*[src/core/tsi/transport_security_interface.h, line 487 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNM3ggtEU_chCYqgaT:-KhNM3ggtEU_chCYqgaU:b-1g8txo) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security_interface.h#L487)):*
> ```objc
> typedef void (*tsi_handshaker_on_next_done_cb)(
>     tsi_result status, void *user_data, const unsigned char *bytes_to_send,
>     size_t bytes_to_send_size, tsi_handshaker_result *handshaker_result);
> ```

As mentioned via email, I think `handshaker_result` can be const.

---

When does `handshaker_result_created` get set?
It will be set by each tsi_handshaker implementation. If it is weird to have child struct modifies the parent struct, we can remove this bool. --- *[src/core/tsi/transport_security.h, line 94 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNMFaGJNjAbQVHtBd_:-KhOppUbh5SzOfMdSdvS:b-e82r9q) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security.h#L94)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
> int frame_protector_created; > int handshaker_result_created; These can probably be `bool`.
Done. I was assuming to use C85, thus avoid to use bool. Per offline discussion with Julien, it seems we are OK to use bool here. --- *[src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c, line 48 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNPIDCdiDYXAYv5gdr:-KhOqJQ_gMYkP1mGpfrC:b-duh4k2) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c#L48)):*
Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
Doesn't this implementation require that the underlying handshaker continue to exist until after the tsi_handshaker_result is destroyed? How do we guarantee that? Perhaps we need to refcount the handshaker object? Or can we just assume that the few applications that will use this adapter will do the right thing until the adapter goes away?
This is a temporary wrapper. We assume the user of this adapter use this correctly. For example, the underlying tsi_handshaker does not allow to use get_peer after create_frame_protector is called. Same limitation for this wrapper. We will remove this wrapper after migration. --- *[src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c, line 88 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNOvlQzA3LPzqLZfdt:-KhOqj2xnhHn-sVSKAE_:b-896fix) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c#L88)):*

Review status: all files reviewed at latest revision, 20 unresolved discussions, some commit checks failed. --- *[src/core/tsi/transport_security.c, line 196 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNMnI5UkhsgbTFvt60:-KhSJArmyExEOwbOlP4p:b-ih70jy) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security.c#L196)):*
Previously, jiangtaoli2016 (Jiangtao Li) wrote…
It will be set by each tsi_handshaker implementation. If it is weird to have child struct modifies the parent struct, we can remove this bool.
Having the subclass modify the data in the parent class is workable. As an alternative, you could have the parent class do this directly by checking whether the subclass returns a result. For the sync case, you could handle that right in this function, using something like this: ``` const tsi_result retval = self->vtable->next(...); if (*handshaker_result != NULL) self->handshaker_result_created = true; return retval; ``` For the async case, this would require intercepting the callback on the way back up (i.e., store the original callback in the parent, have the parent pass its own callback to the subclass, and have that callback set `handshaker_result_created` and then invoke the original callback). I can live with either way, so I'll leave this up to you. Also, note that regardless of whether the parent class or subclass sets this field, you will probably need locking in the async case, because this variable will be updated from a different thread. --- *[src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter., line 0 at r5](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhOrxxGVkO65hQa8U6a:-KhOrxxHJfWVblBe_70W:borrlp3) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/e69881de7fd5a2f09ad92986c48e5fa2a013bb34/src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.#L0)):* I assume that adding this file was a mistake? --- *[src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c, line 88 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNOvlQzA3LPzqLZfdt:-KhSL202RVyVTvOTQlLp:bslacs5) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c#L88)):*

Previously, markdroth (Mark D. Roth) wrote…
Having the subclass modify the data in the parent class is workable. As an alternative, you could have the parent class do this directly by checking whether the subclass returns a result. For the sync case, you could handle that right in this function, using something like this: ``` const tsi_result retval = self->vtable->next(...); if (*handshaker_result != NULL) self->handshaker_result_created = true; return retval; ``` For the async case, this would require intercepting the callback on the way back up (i.e., store the original callback in the parent, have the parent pass its own callback to the subclass, and have that callback set `handshaker_result_created` and then invoke the original callback). I can live with either way, so I'll leave this up to you. Also, note that regardless of whether the parent class or subclass sets this field, you will probably need locking in the async case, because this variable will be updated from a different thread.
Acknowledged. Agree that we need proper locking for ASYNC implementation. I prefer letting underlying tsi handshaker implementation set the handshaker_result_created value. For async implementation of tsi_handshaker_next, we do not require the tsi_handshaker to set the input bytes_to_send, bytes_to_send_size, and handshaker_result, they could even be NULL. --- *[src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c, line 88 at r2](https://reviewable.io:443/reviews/grpc/grpc/10522#-KhNOvlQzA3LPzqLZfdt:-KhTK3tdU0JOCSPCMYzx:busczh) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/d5a241476b65160cf54d96deb5b9510017e3bf0f/src/core/tsi/transport_security_adapter.c#L88)):*
